cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
who caused to build qutub minar in delhi
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
The Qutub Minar is a prominent historical monument located in Delhi, India. It was commissioned by Qutb al-Din Aibak, the founder of the Delhi Sultanate, in the year 1193. The construction of the Qutub Minar was initiated to celebrate the victory over the last Hindu ruler of Delhi and to mark the establishment of Muslim rule in the region. The minaret was intended to serve as a minaret for the nearby Quwwat-ul-Islam Mosque, which was also built during this period. The architectural style of the Qutub Minar reflects the Indo-Islamic style prevalent during that time.

Answer:
Qutb al-Din Aibak caused the construction of the Qutub Minar in Delhi.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
who caused to build qutub minar in delhi
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
["BULLET::::- The Qutub Minar is located in Qutb complex, Mehrauli in South Delhi. It was built by Qutub-ud-din Aibak of the Slave Dynasty, founder of the Delhi Sultanate, started construction of the Qutub Minar's first storey around 1192. In 1220, Aibak's successor and son-in-law Iltutmish completed a further three storeys. In 1369, a lightning strike destroyed the top storey. Firoz Shah Tughlaq replaced the damaged storey, and added one more.. It is a fluted red sandstone tower, which tapers up to a height of 72.5 meters and is covered with intricate carvings and verses from the Qur'an.\n", 'The Mini Qutub Minar ("local:" Chhota Qutub Minar, Mini Minar, Kaushal Minar, Hastsal ki Laat) is a minaret tower in Hastsal village in Uttam Nagar, West Delhi, India. It was built in the 1650 by Mughal emperor, Shah Jahan (reign, 1628-1658) near his hunting lodge in Hasthal. The three storeyed tower is 16.87 meters (55 feet) tall and stands on a raised octagonal platform. The minar is built with bricks and clad with red sandstone. The tower structure and design resembles the Qutub Minar of Delhi and was inspired by it.\n', 'The Qutb complex are monuments and buildings from the Delhi Sultanate at Mehrauli in Delhi in India. The Qutub Minar "victory tower" in the complex, named after the religious figure Qutbuddin Bakhtiar Kaki, was begun by Qutb-ud-din Aibak, who later became the first Sultan of Delhi of the Mamluk dynasty. Construction was continued by his successor Iltutmish (a.k.a. Altamash), and finally completed much later by Firoz Shah Tughlaq, a Sultan of Delhi from the Tughlaq dynasty in 1368 AD. The Qubbat-ul-Islam Mosque (Dome of Islam), later corrupted into Quwwat-ul Islam, stands next to the Qutb Minar.\n', "Following the formation of local government by the United Front in April 1954, the anniversary of 21 February was declared a holiday and it became possible to construct the new monument. A foundation stone was laid in 1956. Sculptor Hamidur Rahman created the design of Shaheed Minar under which construction was started in 1957. Hamidur Rahman's model was a huge complex on a large area of land in the yard of Dhaka Medical College Hostel. The enormous design included a half-circular column to symbolise the mother with her fallen sons standing on the monument's central dais. Yellow and deep blue pieces of stained glass, symbolising eyes reflecting the sun, were also to be placed in the columns. The marble floor was designed to reflect the moving shadows of the columns. The basement of the Minar also included a fresco depicting the history of the language movement. A railing decorated with Bengali alphabet was to be constructed in front. Two footmarks coloured red and black, indicating the two opposite forces, were also in the design. Besides this a museum and a library were also included in Hamidur Rahman's design. A fountain shaped like an eye was also to be constructed. Rahman specifically designed the materials of the monument to withstand the area's tropical climate.\n", "Qutb ud Din Aibak, founder of the Delhi Sultanate, started construction of the Qutb Minar's first storey around 1192. In 1220, Aibak's successor and son-in-law Shamsuddin Iltutmish completed a further three storeys. In 1369, a lightning strike destroyed the top storey. Firoz Shah Tughlaq replaced the damaged storey, and added one more. Sher Shah Suri also added an entrance to this tower while he was ruling and Humayun was in exile.\n", 'BULLET::::- 1190s – Construction of Qutub Minar started in India\n', 'Letitia Elizabeth Landon\'s poem "The Qutub Minar, Delhi" is a reflection on an engraving in Fisher\'s Drawing Room Scrap Book, 1833.\n', 'The Mini Qutub Minar structure is similar to Qutub Minar in Delhi. It originally consisted of five storeys, each with a reducing diameter. A narrow staircase built inside led to the top. Each storey is surrounded by an octagonal ring in the outside with red sandstone overhanging eves (Chhajja) like in the Qutub Minar. The minar is built using Lakhori bricks.\n', 'In the early 17th century, Mughal emperor, Shah Jahan used Hastsal as one of his hunting lodges. In 1650, he commissioned the construction of a tall minaret similar to Qutub Minar in Delhi. When completed, the Mini Qutub Minar was much higher than it is now. It was a tall 5 storey tower with an internal stairway leading to the domed Chhatri pavilion at the top. It was a gorgeous hunting pavilion tower in the center of an encompassing wilderness. The emperor rested in the tower top, royally-entertained with his immediate retinue after hunting in the surrounding wilderness.\n', 'The minar\'s topmost storey was damaged by lightning in 1369 and was rebuilt by Firuz Shah Tughlaq, who added another storey. In 1505, an earthquake damaged Qutub Minar; it was repaired by Sikander Lodi. On 1 September 1803, a major earthquake caused serious damage. Major Robert Smith of the British Indian Army renovated the tower in 1828 and installed a pillared cupola over the fifth storey, thus creating a sixth. The cupola was taken down in 1848, under instructions from The Viscount Hardinge, then Governor General of India. It was reinstalled at ground level to the east of Qutb Minar, where it remains. It is known as "Smith\'s Folly".\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To provide a comprehensive understanding of the Qutub Minar and its historical context, we can extract and analyze several key pieces of information from the provided passages. This will help clarify the origins of the Qutub Minar and the figures involved in its construction.

### Extracted Content and Analysis:

1. **Qutub-ud-din Aibak**:
   - **Role**: Founder of the Delhi Sultanate and initiator of the Qutub Minar's construction.
   - **Contribution**: He began the construction of the first storey around 1192.
   - **Significance**: Aibak's role is crucial as he represents the establishment of Muslim rule in India, marking the beginning of the Delhi Sultanate.

2. **Iltutmish**:
   - **Role**: Aibak's successor and son-in-law.
   - **Contribution**: Completed three additional storeys of the Qutub Minar by 1220.
   - **Significance**: His involvement indicates the continuation of Aibak's vision and the importance of the Qutub Minar as a symbol of power and architectural achievement during the early Sultanate period.

3. **Firoz Shah Tughlaq**:
   - **Role**: A later Sultan of Delhi.
   - **Contribution**: Rebuilt the top storey after it was damaged by lightning in 1369 and added an additional storey.
   - **Significance**: His contributions reflect the ongoing maintenance and reverence for the Qutub Minar as a historical monument, showcasing the importance of preservation in Islamic architecture.

4. **Architectural Features**:
   - **Description**: The Qutub Minar is a fluted red sandstone tower, tapering to a height of 72.5 meters, adorned with intricate carvings and verses from the Qur'an.
   - **Significance**: These features highlight the artistic and cultural values of the time, as well as the integration of religious elements into architectural designs.

5. **Historical Context**:
   - **Timeline**: Construction began in the late 12th century and continued into the 14th century, with various rulers contributing to its completion and maintenance.
   - **Significance**: This timeline places the Qutub Minar within a broader historical narrative of the Delhi Sultanate, illustrating the transitions in power and the evolution of architectural styles over time.

6. **Cultural Symbolism**:
   - **Name Origin**: The Qutub Minar is named after Qutbuddin Bakhtiar Kaki, a revered Sufi saint.
   - **Significance**: This connection to Sufism reflects the spiritual and cultural dimensions of the monument, indicating its role not just as a physical structure but as a symbol of Islamic faith and heritage in India.

### Conclusion:
The extracted content provides a deeper understanding of the Qutub Minar's construction, the historical figures involved, and the architectural significance of the monument. This context is essential for answering the question of who caused the Qutub Minar to be built, as it highlights the collaborative efforts of multiple rulers over time and the cultural importance of the structure in the history of Delhi and India as a whole. Understanding these elements enriches the narrative surrounding the Qutub Minar and situates it within the broader tapestry of Indian history.

knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

The Qutub Minar is a significant historical monument located in Delhi, India, and its construction is attributed to several key figures from the Delhi Sultanate era. The reasoning process begins with identifying the primary initiator of the Qutub Minar's construction, Qutb al-Din Aibak, who was the founder of the Delhi Sultanate. He commissioned the construction around 1192, shortly after his victory over the last Hindu ruler of Delhi, marking the establishment of Muslim rule in the region. This context is essential as it highlights the political and cultural motivations behind the monument's construction.

Aibak's successor, Iltutmish, played a crucial role in the Qutub Minar's development by completing three additional storeys by 1220. This continuation of construction signifies the importance of the Qutub Minar as a symbol of power and architectural achievement during the early Sultanate period. Furthermore, Firoz Shah Tughlaq, another significant ruler, later rebuilt the top storey after it was damaged by lightning in 1369 and added an additional storey. His contributions reflect the ongoing reverence for the Qutub Minar as a historical monument and the importance of preservation in Islamic architecture.

The architectural features of the Qutub Minar, such as its fluted red sandstone structure, intricate carvings, and verses from the Qur'an, showcase the artistic and cultural values of the time. The minaret served as a functional element for the nearby Quwwat-ul-Islam Mosque, emphasizing the integration of religious elements into architectural designs.

Additionally, the name "Qutub Minar" is derived from Qutbuddin Bakhtiar Kaki, a revered Sufi saint, which adds a layer of cultural and spiritual significance to the monument. This connection to Sufism reflects the broader spiritual and cultural dimensions of the monument, indicating its role not just as a physical structure but as a symbol of Islamic faith and heritage in India.

In summary, the Qutub Minar's construction is a collaborative effort involving multiple rulers over time, each contributing to its architectural and cultural significance. Understanding these elements enriches the narrative surrounding the Qutub Minar and situates it within the broader tapestry of Indian history.

### Answer:
Qutb al-Din Aibak initiated the construction of the Qutub Minar in Delhi around 1192, with significant contributions from his successor Iltutmish, who completed additional storeys, and Firoz Shah Tughlaq, who later rebuilt and added to the structure. The Qutub Minar serves as a symbol of the establishment of Muslim rule in India and reflects the architectural and cultural values of the time.

To answer the question of who caused the construction of the Qutub Minar in Delhi, we can extract and synthesize relevant information from the provided passages.

1. **Initial Construction**: The Qutub Minar was initiated by **Qutub-ud-din Aibak**, who was the founder of the Delhi Sultanate. He began the construction of the first storey around **1192**. This establishes Aibak as the primary figure responsible for the inception of the Qutub Minar.

2. **Completion of the Structure**: The construction was not completed solely by Aibak. His successor and son-in-law, **Iltutmish**, continued the work and completed an additional three storeys by **1220**. This indicates that the project was a continuation of Aibak's vision and was further developed under Iltutmish's rule.

3. **Subsequent Modifications**: The Qutub Minar underwent further modifications after its initial completion. In **1369**, a lightning strike damaged the top storey, which was then replaced by **Firoz Shah Tughlaq**, who added an additional storey. This highlights that the Qutub Minar was not only a product of its original builders but also a structure that evolved over time through the contributions of later rulers.

4. **Cultural and Historical Context**: The Qutub Minar is part of the **Qutb complex**, which includes various monuments from the Delhi Sultanate era. The minaret is named after **Qutbuddin Bakhtiar Kaki**, a revered Sufi saint, which reflects the cultural and religious significance of the structure beyond its architectural value.

5. **Architectural Significance**: The Qutub Minar is notable for its fluted red sandstone design, intricate carvings, and verses from the Qur'an, which not only showcases the architectural style of the time but also its religious importance.

In summary, the construction of the Qutub Minar was initiated by **Qutub-ud-din Aibak** around **1192**, with significant contributions from **Iltutmish** who completed additional storeys by **1220**, and later modifications by **Firoz Shah Tughlaq** in **1369**. This layered history of construction and modification reflects the minaret's importance as both a monumental structure and a symbol of the evolving political and cultural landscape of Delhi during the Sultanate period. Thus, the answer to the question is that Qutub-ud-din Aibak is credited with starting the construction, while Iltutmish and Firoz Shah Tughlaq played crucial roles in its completion and enhancement.

["BULLET::::- The Qutub Minar is located in Qutb complex, Mehrauli in South Delhi. It was built by Qutub-ud-din Aibak of the Slave Dynasty, founder of the Delhi Sultanate, started construction of the Qutub Minar's first storey around 1192. In 1220, Aibak's successor and son-in-law Iltutmish completed a further three storeys. In 1369, a lightning strike destroyed the top storey. Firoz Shah Tughlaq replaced the damaged storey, and added one more.. It is a fluted red sandstone tower, which tapers up to a height of 72.5 meters and is covered with intricate carvings and verses from the Qur'an.
", 'The Mini Qutub Minar ("local:" Chhota Qutub Minar, Mini Minar, Kaushal Minar, Hastsal ki Laat) is a minaret tower in Hastsal village in Uttam Nagar, West Delhi, India. It was built in the 1650 by Mughal emperor, Shah Jahan (reign, 1628-1658) near his hunting lodge in Hasthal. The three storeyed tower is 16.87 meters (55 feet) tall and stands on a raised octagonal platform. The minar is built with bricks and clad with red sandstone. The tower structure and design resembles the Qutub Minar of Delhi and was inspired by it.
', 'The Qutb complex are monuments and buildings from the Delhi Sultanate at Mehrauli in Delhi in India. The Qutub Minar "victory tower" in the complex, named after the religious figure Qutbuddin Bakhtiar Kaki, was begun by Qutb-ud-din Aibak, who later became the first Sultan of Delhi of the Mamluk dynasty. Construction was continued by his successor Iltutmish (a.k.a. Altamash), and finally completed much later by Firoz Shah Tughlaq, a Sultan of Delhi from the Tughlaq dynasty in 1368 AD. The Qubbat-ul-Islam Mosque (Dome of Islam), later corrupted into Quwwat-ul Islam, stands next to the Qutb Minar.
', "Following the formation of local government by the United Front in April 1954, the anniversary of 21 February was declared a holiday and it became possible to construct the new monument. A foundation stone was laid in 1956. Sculptor Hamidur Rahman created the design of Shaheed Minar under which construction was started in 1957. Hamidur Rahman's model was a huge complex on a large area of land in the yard of Dhaka Medical College Hostel. The enormous design included a half-circular column to symbolise the mother with her fallen sons standing on the monument's central dais. Yellow and deep blue pieces of stained glass, symbolising eyes reflecting the sun, were also to be placed in the columns. The marble floor was designed to reflect the moving shadows of the columns. The basement of the Minar also included a fresco depicting the history of the language movement. A railing decorated with Bengali alphabet was to be constructed in front. Two footmarks coloured red and black, indicating the two opposite forces, were also in the design. Besides this a museum and a library were also included in Hamidur Rahman's design. A fountain shaped like an eye was also to be constructed. Rahman specifically designed the materials of the monument to withstand the area's tropical climate.
", "Qutb ud Din Aibak, founder of the Delhi Sultanate, started construction of the Qutb Minar's first storey around 1192. In 1220, Aibak's successor and son-in-law Shamsuddin Iltutmish completed a further three storeys. In 1369, a lightning strike destroyed the top storey. Firoz Shah Tughlaq replaced the damaged storey, and added one more. Sher Shah Suri also added an entrance to this tower while he was ruling and Humayun was in exile.
", 'BULLET::::- 1190s – Construction of Qutub Minar started in India
', 'Letitia Elizabeth Landon's poem "The Qutub Minar, Delhi" is a reflection on an engraving in Fisher's Drawing Room Scrap Book, 1833.
', 'The Mini Qutub Minar structure is similar to Qutub Minar in Delhi. It originally consisted of five storeys, each with a reducing diameter. A narrow staircase built inside led to the top. Each storey is surrounded by an octagonal ring in the outside with red sandstone overhanging eves (Chhajja) like in the Qutub Minar. The minar is built using Lakhori bricks.
', 'In the early 17th century, Mughal emperor, Shah Jahan used Hastsal as one of his hunting lodges. In 1650, he commissioned the construction of a tall minaret similar to Qutub Minar in Delhi. When completed, the Mini Qutub Minar was much higher than it is now. It was a tall 5 storey tower with an internal stairway leading to the domed Chhatri pavilion at the top. It was a gorgeous hunting pavilion tower in the center of an encompassing wilderness. The emperor rested in the tower top, royally-entertained with his immediate retinue after hunting in the surrounding wilderness.
', 'The minar's topmost storey was damaged by lightning in 1369 and was rebuilt by Firuz Shah Tughlaq, who added another storey. In 1505, an earthquake damaged Qutub Minar; it was repaired by Sikander Lodi. On 1 September 1803, a major earthquake caused serious damage. Major Robert Smith of the British Indian Army renovated the tower in 1828 and installed a pillared cupola over the fifth storey, thus creating a sixth. The cupola was taken down in 1848, under instructions from The Viscount Hardinge, then Governor General of India. It was reinstalled at ground level to the east of Qutb Minar, where it remains. It is known as "Smith's Folly".
']

Task Description:
Please extract content from these passages that can help enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities.
consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate relevant information from the provided passages regarding the construction of the Qutub Minar in Delhi. Here’s a breakdown of the key points:

### Extracted Information:
1. **Initiation of Construction**:
   - The Qutub Minar was initiated by **Qutub-ud-din Aibak**, the founder of the Delhi Sultanate, around **1192**.

2. **Completion of Storeys**:
   - Aibak's successor, **Iltutmish**, completed three additional storeys by **1220**.
   - **Firoz Shah Tughlaq** later replaced the top storey after it was damaged by lightning in **1369** and added one more storey.

3. **Historical Context**:
   - The Qutub Minar is part of the **Qutb complex**, which includes other significant monuments from the Delhi Sultanate era.
   - The minar is named after the religious figure **Qutbuddin Bakhtiar Kaki**.

4. **Subsequent Modifications**:
   - Other rulers, such as **Sher Shah Suri** and **Sikander Lodi**, made modifications and repairs to the structure over the years.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:
1. **Understanding Causality**:
   - The timeline of events (initiation by Aibak, completion by Iltutmish, and repairs by Firoz Shah Tughlaq) illustrates a clear causal relationship between the actions of different rulers and the construction and preservation of the Qutub Minar. This helps the model understand how sequential actions lead to a final outcome.

2. **Identifying Key Actors**:
   - Recognizing the roles of various historical figures (Aibak, Iltutmish, Firoz Shah Tughlaq) allows the model to infer how individual decisions and leadership styles can impact large-scale projects. This enhances the model's ability to analyze the influence of specific agents in historical contexts.

3. **Contextualizing Historical Events**:
   - The information about the Qutub Minar being part of a larger complex and its naming after a religious figure provides context that can help the model understand the cultural and political significance of the structure. This contextual knowledge is crucial for making inferences about the motivations behind construction and modifications.

4. **Recognizing Patterns**:
   - The model can learn to recognize patterns in historical construction projects, such as the common practice of rulers commissioning monuments to signify power or commemorate events. This pattern recognition can improve the model's ability to draw parallels in different contexts.

5. **Temporal Reasoning**:
   - The chronological sequence of events aids in developing temporal reasoning skills, allowing the model to understand how past actions influence future developments, which is essential for causal reasoning.

### Conclusion:
By consolidating the extracted information and analyzing its implications, we can enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities. The model can learn to identify relationships between actions and outcomes, understand the significance of historical figures, and contextualize events within broader cultural narratives. This multifaceted understanding is crucial for improving the model's reasoning abilities in historical and causal contexts.

question:
who caused to build qutub minar in delhi
answer:
Reasoning process:
The Qutub Minar is a prominent historical monument located in Delhi, India. It was commissioned by Qutb al-Din Aibak, the founder of the Delhi Sultanate, in the year 1193. The construction of the Qutub Minar was initiated to celebrate the victory over the last Hindu ruler of Delhi and to mark the establishment of Muslim rule in the region. The minaret was intended to serve as a minaret for the nearby Quwwat-ul-Islam Mosque, which was also built during this period. The architectural style of the Qutub Minar reflects the Indo-Islamic style prevalent during that time.

Answer:
Qutb al-Din Aibak caused the construction of the Qutub Minar in Delhi.

**Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:**

The Qutub Minar is a significant historical monument located in Delhi, India. It was commissioned by **Qutb-ud-din Aibak**, the founder of the Delhi Sultanate, around **1192**. The construction of the Qutub Minar was initiated to celebrate the victory over the last Hindu ruler of Delhi and to mark the establishment of Muslim rule in the region. The minaret was intended to serve as a minaret for the nearby **Quwwat-ul-Islam Mosque**, which was also built during this period. 

The construction of the Qutub Minar was not solely the work of Aibak; his successor and son-in-law, **Iltutmish**, completed three additional storeys by **1220**, showcasing the collaborative nature of the project. Furthermore, the top storey was rebuilt by **Firoz Shah Tughlaq** after it was damaged by lightning in **1369**, and he added an additional storey, indicating ongoing maintenance and enhancement of the structure over time.

The Qutub Minar is part of the **Qutb complex**, which includes other significant monuments from the Delhi Sultanate era, providing a broader historical context. It is named after **Qutbuddin Bakhtiar Kaki**, a revered Sufi saint, adding cultural and religious significance to the structure. Architecturally, the Qutub Minar is a **fluted red sandstone tower** that tapers to a height of **72.5 meters**, adorned with intricate carvings and verses from the Qur'an, reflecting the Indo-Islamic architectural style of the time.

Additionally, the Minar has undergone various repairs and renovations due to natural disasters, including earthquakes in **1505** and **1803**, which highlights its historical resilience and the efforts made to preserve it.

By integrating these details, the model can enhance its understanding of the Qutub Minar's construction, historical significance, and architectural features, thereby reducing the likelihood of inaccuracies or oversights in future responses.

**Answer:**
Qutb-ud-din Aibak initiated the construction of the Qutub Minar in Delhi around 1192. His successor, Iltutmish, completed three additional storeys by 1220, and Firoz Shah Tughlaq later rebuilt the top storey after it was damaged by lightning in 1369. The Qutub Minar is part of the Qutb complex and is named after the Sufi saint Qutbuddin Bakhtiar Kaki. It stands at a height of 72.5 meters and features intricate carvings and verses from the Qur'an, reflecting the Indo-Islamic architectural style.

The Qutb complex are monuments and buildings from the Delhi Sultanate at Mehrauli in Delhi in India. The Qutub Minar "victory tower" in the complex, named after the religious figure Qutbuddin Bakhtiar Kaki, was begun by Qutb-ud-din Aibak, who later became the first Sultan of Delhi of the Mamluk dynasty. Construction was continued by his successor Iltutmish (a.k.a. Altamash), and finally completed much later by Firoz Shah Tughlaq, a Sultan of Delhi from the Tughlaq dynasty in 1368 AD. The Qubbat-ul-Islam Mosque (Dome of Islam), later corrupted into Quwwat-ul Islam, stands next to the Qutb Minar.
Following the formation of local government by the United Front in April 1954, the anniversary of 21 February was declared a holiday and it became possible to construct the new monument. A foundation stone was laid in 1956. Sculptor Hamidur Rahman created the design of Shaheed Minar under which construction was started in 1957. Hamidur Rahman's model was a huge complex on a large area of land in the yard of Dhaka Medical College Hostel. The enormous design included a half-circular column to symbolise the mother with her fallen sons standing on the monument's central dais. Yellow and deep blue pieces of stained glass, symbolising eyes reflecting the sun, were also to be placed in the columns. The marble floor was designed to reflect the moving shadows of the columns. The basement of the Minar also included a fresco depicting the history of the language movement. A railing decorated with Bengali alphabet was to be constructed in front. Two footmarks coloured red and black, indicating the two opposite forces, were also in the design. Besides this a museum and a library were also included in Hamidur Rahman's design. A fountain shaped like an eye was also to be constructed. Rahman specifically designed the materials of the monument to withstand the area's tropical climate.
Qutb ud Din Aibak, founder of the Delhi Sultanate, started construction of the Qutb Minar's first storey around 1192. In 1220, Aibak's successor and son-in-law Shamsuddin Iltutmish completed a further three storeys. In 1369, a lightning strike destroyed the top storey. Firoz Shah Tughlaq replaced the damaged storey, and added one more. Sher Shah Suri also added an entrance to this tower while he was ruling and Humayun was in exile.
BULLET::::- 1190s – Construction of Qutub Minar started in India
Letitia Elizabeth Landon's poem "The Qutub Minar, Delhi" is a reflection on an engraving in Fisher's Drawing Room Scrap Book, 1833.
The Mini Qutub Minar structure is similar to Qutub Minar in Delhi. It originally consisted of five storeys, each with a reducing diameter. A narrow staircase built inside led to the top. Each storey is surrounded by an octagonal ring in the outside with red sandstone overhanging eves (Chhajja) like in the Qutub Minar. The minar is built using Lakhori bricks.
In the early 17th century, Mughal emperor, Shah Jahan used Hastsal as one of his hunting lodges. In 1650, he commissioned the construction of a tall minaret similar to Qutub Minar in Delhi. When completed, the Mini Qutub Minar was much higher than it is now. It was a tall 5 storey tower with an internal stairway leading to the domed Chhatri pavilion at the top. It was a gorgeous hunting pavilion tower in the center of an encompassing wilderness. The emperor rested in the tower top, royally-entertained with his immediate retinue after hunting in the surrounding wilderness.
The minar's topmost storey was damaged by lightning in 1369 and was rebuilt by Firuz Shah Tughlaq, who added another storey. In 1505, an earthquake damaged Qutub Minar; it was repaired by Sikander Lodi. On 1 September 1803, a major earthquake caused serious damage. Major Robert Smith of the British Indian Army renovated the tower in 1828 and installed a pillared cupola over the fifth storey, thus creating a sixth. The cupola was taken down in 1848, under instructions from The Viscount Hardinge, then Governor General of India. It was reinstalled at ground level to the east of Qutb Minar, where it remains. It is known as "Smith's Folly".
